abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs, by and large, with
            the Implementation Completion Report (ICR) and Evaluation
            Summary (ES) ratings of a satisfactory project outcome,
            likely sustainability, and satisfactory performances by both
            the Bank and Borrower; however, it upgrades the
            institutional development impact from substantial to high.
            The experience of this project offers three lessons: 1)
            Regionally-sponsored environmental initiatives responsive to
            inter-governmental action plans, provide good opportunities
            for the Bank to exercise its comparative advantage in
            leveraging institutional reform through targeted lending.
            When linked with grant funding from bilateral development
            partners, it provides a powerful, and influential lobby for
            reform. 2) When designing, and implementing regional
            environmental initiatives and their specific projects,
            significant benefits can be achieved by addressing
            infrastructure investments, environmental management
            activities, and capacity building in an integrated manner.
            Multiplier effects will be achieved by careful attention,
            and support for development of local institutions. and their
            human resources. 3) It is important to fully understand the
            interests, and institutional capabilities of local
            stakeholders, specifically for community based activities,
            and to factor in sufficient time, and resources to build a
            consensus for reform, and agreement on issues, and
            longer-term objectives. Project activities being solely
            driven by external partners, should be carefully avoided, as
            this can undermine local ownership.
